review.title: Strength Factors: An Uncertainty System for a Quantified Modal Logic
review.abstract: We present a new system S for handling uncertainty in a quantified modal logic (first-order modal logic). The system is based on both probability theory and proof theory. The system is derived from Chisholm's epistemology. We concretize Chisholm's system by grounding his undefined and primitive (i.e. foundational) concept of reasonablenes in probability and proof theory. S can be useful in systems that have to interact with humans and provide justifications for their uncertainty. As a demonstration of the system, we apply the system to provide a solution to the lottery paradox. Another advantage of the system is that it can be used to provide uncertainty values for counterfactual statements. Counterfactuals are statements that an agent knows for sure are false. Among other cases, counterfactuals are useful when systems have to explain their actions to users. Uncertainties for counterfactuals fall out naturally from our system.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The quantified modal logic we use is based on the deontic cognitive event calculation (DCEC), which belongs to the family of cognitive calculations used in modelling complex cognitions. Specifically, we are adding a system of uncertainty derived from Chisholm's epistemology [Chisholm, 1987].1 System S is a work in progress, and therefore the presentation here will be inherently abstract. One of our primary motivations is to design a system of uncertainty that is easy for end users to use. There are many studies showing that laymen have difficulty understanding raw probability values (see e.g. [Kaye and Koehler, 1991]); and we believe that our philosophy-based approach can pave the way to present uncertain statements in a more comprehensible format.

sections.heading: 5 Usage
sections.text: In this section, we illustrate S by applying it to solve fundamental problems such as the lottery paradox [Kyburg Jr., 1961, p. 197] and a toy version of a real example, a murder riddle example (based on the traditions of logic pedagogy). Finally, we very briefly outline abstract scenarios in which S can be used to generate uncertainty values for counterfactual statements and to generate explanations for actions.

sections.heading: 5.4 Explanations
sections.text: The definitions of the above strength factors and reasonableness can be used to create high-level explanatory schemes that can be used instead of a simple representation of the raw probability values for the end user. Although we have not specified these explanatory schemes, we illustrate a possible scheme: Say an agent performs an action α on the basis of φ. In this case, the agent could generate a statement that merely states at the highest level that it is more reasonable for the agent to believe in φ than for the agent to believe in Celsius. The agent could then further explain why it was reasonable for him by using one of the three clauses in the definition of reasonableness.

sections.heading: 6 Inference Algorithm Sketch
sections.text: The detailed description of the inference algorithm goes beyond the scope of this paper, but here we provide a sketch at the highest level. [6] Our calculation of evidence is merely an extension of the standard firstorder-proof calculation under various modal contexts. For example, if a believes that b believes in a number of propositions, a believes that b believes, and we believe that B. We convert B (a, ta, B (b, tb, Q) to the pure formula Q of the first order (context (a, ta, b, tb)) and use a first order prover. The conversion process is somewhat more nuanced as we have to deal with negations, deal properly with substitutions of equities, uncertainties, and transform compound formulas within repeated beliefs.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have outlined the first steps towards building a system of uncertainty based on both probability and evidence theory that could be suitable for (1) solving fundamental problems; (2) useful for applications; (3) generating uncertainty values for counterfactors; and (4) building understandable explanations. Many challenges remain, some relatively simple and others quite difficult. Simple challenges include defining and experimenting with different candidates for PR, BRD, BRD and BRD countries. On the more difficult side, we need to find comprehensible arithmetic mechanisms for calculating the minimal < BRD, BRD > in the definition of BRD. Also, on the difficult side, there is the challenge of developing efficient argumentation programs. Although we have an exact follow-up algorithm, we believe that an approximate set of beliefs is selectively discarded in a large knowledge base during reasoning.

metadata.abstractText: We present a new system S for handling uncertainty in a quantified modal logic (first-order modal logic). The system is based on both probability theory and proof theory. The system is derived from Chisholm’s epistemology. We concretize Chisholm’s system by grounding his undefined and primitive (i.e. foundational) concept of reasonableness in probability and proof theory. S can be useful in systems that have to interact with humans and provide justifications for their uncertainty. As a demonstration of the system, we apply the system to provide a solution to the lottery paradox. Another advantage of the system is that it can be used to provide uncertainty values for counterfactual statements. Counterfactuals are statements that an agent knows for sure are false. Among other cases, counterfactuals are useful when systems have to explain their actions to users (If I had not done α, then φ would have happened). Uncertainties for counterfactuals fall out naturally from our system. Efficient reasoning in just simple first-order logic is a hard problem. Resolution-based first-order reasoning systems have made significant progress over the last several decades in building systems that have solved non-trivial tasks (even unsolved conjectures in mathematics). We present a sketch of a novel algorithm for reasoning that extends firstorder resolution. Finally, while there have been many systems of uncertainty for propositional logics, first-order logics and propositional modal logics, there has been very little work in building systems of uncertainty for first-order modal logics. The work described below is in progress; and once finished will address this lack.
